ranked_diseases.explanation: Both reference cases 2 and 3 with hyperuricemia were diagnosed with this condition. This is a hereditary kidney disease that commonly presents with isolated hyperuricemia in young patients before progression to chronic kidney disease.
Another form of autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease that can present with hyperuricemia. Similar clinical presentation to type 1 but caused by mutations in different genes.
This is essentially the same as ADTKD-1 but represents the earlier nomenclature. Presents with hyperuricemia in adolescence/young adulthood before kidney disease develops.
HPRT deficiency (Lesch-Nyhan syndrome spectrum) can present with isolated hyperuricemia in milder forms. Given the patient is male, this X-linked condition should be considered.
X-linked disorder causing overproduction of uric acid. Can present with isolated hyperuricemia in adolescence, particularly in males.
GSD type I can present with hyperuricemia due to competition between lactate and uric acid for renal excretion. However, usually has additional metabolic features not mentioned here.
